intro: Comocladia macrophylla, commonly known as the broadleaf sea grape, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of Southeast Asia. It is a shrub or small tree that typically grows in saline or brackish environments, such as mangrove swamps and tidal flats. The plant has alternate, simple, and often革质 (leathery) leaves that are elliptical in shape and can reach up to 20 centimeters in length. Its flowers are small, white, and clustered in inflorescences, and it produces small, fleshy fruits that are edible. The plant is well adapted to coastal conditions, with a deep root system that helps it withstand saltwater and tidal influences.
